After having fasted during the eleventh day of the bright half of the month Mârgasîrsha, let aman worship, on the twelfth day, the venerable Vâsudeva (Vishnu).
(He shall worship him) with flowers, incense, unguents, lamps, eatables (such as milk), and repasts given to Brâhmanas.
By performing this rite (on the twelfth day of the bright half of every month, from the month Mârgasîrsha to the month Kârttika) for one year, he is purified from every sin.
By performing it till he dies, he attains Svetadvîpa ('the white island,' the abode of Bhagavat).
By performing it for a year on each twelfth day of both halves of a month, he attains heaven.
By performing it (within the same intervals), till he dies, (he attains) the world of Vishnu.
The same (heavenly rewards are gained by him who performs this rite) on each fifteenth day (after having fasted during the fourteenth).

If he worships (according to the latter rite) Kesava (Vishnu) who has become one with Brahman, on the day of full moon, and Kesava absorbed in meditation, on the day of new moon, he will obtain a great reward.
If in a year on a day of full moon the moon and the planet Jupiter are seen together in the sky, it is called a great full moon.
Gifts, fasts, and the like are declared to be imperishable on that day. The same is the case if a conjunction with the asterism. Sravanâ falls on the twelfth day of the bright half (of any month).
Let a man make a hut of leaves in a forest and dwell in it;
And let him bathe (and perform his prayers) three times a day;
And let him collect alms, going from one village to another, and proclaiming his own deed;
And let him sleep upon grass:
This is called a Mahâvrata (great observance).
He who has killed a Brâhmana (unintentionally) must perform it for twelve years.
(He who has unintentionally killed) a Kshatriya or a Vaisya engaged in a sacrifice, for the same period.
Likewise, he who has killed (unintentionally) a pregnant woman, or a woman in her courses.
Or a woman who has bathed after temporary uncleanness;
Or a friend.
He who has (unintentionally) killed a king, must perform the Mahâvrata for twice the same number of years (or twenty-four years);
He who has (unintentionally) killed. a Kshatriya (not engaged in a sacrifice, nor a king), for one quarter of that time less (or for nine years);
He who has (unintentionally) killed a Vaisya (not engaged in a sacrifice), for half of that time (or for six years).
He who has (unintentionally) killed a (virtuous) Sûdra, for half of that time again (or for three years).
He who is performing any of those penances, must carry (on his stick) the skull of the person slain, like a flag.
Let a man serve cows for a month, his hair and beard having been shorn.
And let him sit down to rest when they rest;
And let him stand still when they stand still;
And let him give assistance to a cow that has met with an accident (such as getting into a slough, or falling into a pit).
And let him preserve them from (the attacks of lions and tigers and other) dangers.
Let him not seek shelter himself against cold (and hot winds) and similar dangers, without having previously protected the cows against them.
Let him wash himself with cow-urine (three times a day);
And let him subsist upon the (five) productions of a cow:
This is the Govrata (cow rite), which must be performed by him who has (unintentionally) killed a cow (belonging to a Kshatriya).
If a man has killed an elephant (intentionally), he must give five black (nîla) bulls.
If he has killed (unintentionally) a horse, he must give a garment.
If he has (intentionally) killed an ass, he must give a bull one year old.
The same if he has (intentionally) killed a ram or a goat.
If he has (intentionally) killed a camel, he must give one Krishnala of gold.
If he has (intentionally) killed a dog, he must fast for three days.

If he has (unintentionally) killed a mouse, or a cat, or an ichneumon, or a frog, or a Dundubha snake, or a large serpent (a boa constrictor), he must fast one day, and on the next day he must give a dish of milk, sesamum, and rice mixed together to a Brâhmana, and give him an iron hoe as his 'fee.'
If he has killed (unintentionally) an iguana, or an owl, or a crow, or a fish, he must fast for three days.
If he has killed (intentionally) a Hamsa, or a crane, or a heron, or a cormorant, or an ape, or a falcon, or the vulture called Bhâsa, or a Brâhmanî duck, he must give a cow to a Brâhmana.
If he has killed a snake, (he must give) an iron spade.
If he has killed emasculated (cattle or birds), (he must give) a load of straw.
If he has killed (intentionally) a boar, (he must give) a Kumbha of clarified butter.
If he has (intentionally) killed a partridge, (he must give) a Drona of sesamum.
If he has (intentionally) killed a parrot, (he must give) a calf two years old.
If he has (intentionally) killed a curlew, (he must give) a calf three years old.
If he has (unintentionally) killed a wild carnivorous animal, he must give a milch cow.
If he has (unintentionally) killed a wild animal not carnivorous, (he must give) a heifer.
If he has (intentionally) killed an animal not mentioned before, he must subsist upon milk for three days.
If he has (unintentionally) killed a bird (not mentioned before), he must eat at night only;
Or (if unable to do so), he must give a silver Mâsha.
If he has (unintentionally) killed an aquatic animal, he must fast (for a day and a night).
If he has killed a thousand (small) animals having bones, or an ox-load of animals that have no bones, he must perform the same penance as for killing a Sûdra.

But, if he has killed animals having bones, he must (moreover) give some trifle to a Brâhmana (for each animal which he has killed); if he has killed boneless animals, he becomes purified by one stopping of the breath.

For cutting (unawares?) trees yielding fruit (such as the bread-fruit or mango trees), shrubs, creeping or climbing plants, or plants yielding blossoms (such as the jasmine tree), he must mutter a Vedic text (the Gâyatrî) a hundred times.

For killing (unintentionally) insects bred in rice or other food, or in (sweets and) the like, or in liquids (such as molasses), or elsewhere (in water and so on), or in flowers or fruits, the penance consists in eating clarified butter.

If a man has wantonly cut such plants asgrow by cultivation. (such as rice and barley), or such as rise spontaneously in the wood (such as wild rice), he must wait on a cow and subsist upon milk for one day.
A drinker of spirituous liquor must abstain from all religious rites and subsist on grains separated from the husk for a year.
If a man has (knowingly) tasted any of the (twelve) unclean excretions of the body, or of the (twelve) intoxicating drinks, he must perform the Kândrâyana penance.

Likewise, if he has (knowingly) eaten garlic, or onions, or red garlic, or any plant which has a similar flavour (to that of garlic or onions), or the meat of village pigs, of tame cocks (and other tame birds), of apes, and of cows.
In all those cases men belonging to a twice-born caste have to be initiated a second time, after the penance is over.
On their second initiation, the tonsure, the girding with the sacred string, the wearing of the staff, and the begging of alms shall be omitted.
If a man has (unawares) eaten meat of a fivetoed animal, with the exception of the hare, the porcupine, the iguana, the rhinoceros, and the tortoise, he must fast for seven days.
If he has eaten the food of a multitude of persons, of a harlot, of a thief, or of a singer, he must subsist upon milk for seven days.
And (if he has eaten) the food of a carpenter or of a leather manufacturer;
Or of a usurer, of a miser, of one who has performed the initiatory ceremony of a Soma-sacrifice, of a jailer, of an Abhisasta, or of a eunuch;
Or of a dissolute woman, of a hypocrite, of a physician, of a hunter, of a hard-hearted or cruel person, and of one who eats the leavings of food;
Or of a woman who has neither husband nor son, of a goldsmith, of an enemy, or of an outcast:
Or of a malignant informer, of a liar, of one who has transgressed the law, and of one who sells himself, or who sells (molasses or other) liquids and condiments;
Or of a public dancer, of a weaver, of an ungrateful man, or of a dyer of clothes;
Or (the food) of a blacksmith, of a man of the Nishâda tribe (who subsist by fishing), of a stage-player, of a worker in cane, or of a seller of weapons;
Or of a trainer of dogs, of a distiller of spirituous liquor, of an oil manufacturer, or of a washerman;
Or (the food) of a woman in her courses (whether belonging to her, or dressed for her), or of one who lives under one roof with the paramour of his wife;
Or (food) which has been looked at by the killer of an embryo (of a Brâhmana), or which has been touched by a woman in her courses, or nibbled by a bird, or touched by a dog, or smelt at by a cow;
Or that which has been designedly touched with the foot, or that which has been sneezed at;
Or the food of insane, or wrathful, or sick persons;
Or (food that is given) in a disrespectful manner, or the meat (of animals killed) for no sacred purpose.
After having (unawares) eaten the flesh of any sort of fish, excepting the Pâthîna, Rohita, Râgîva, Simhatunda, and Sakula fishes, he must fast for three days.
Likewise, after having (unawares) eaten the flesh of (any other) aquatic animal (such as the alligator, or the Gangetic porpoise).
After having (knowingly) drunk water from a vessel in which spirituous liquor had been kept, he must drink for seven days milk boiled together with the Sankhapushpî plant.
After having (knowingly drunk water) from a vessel in which an intoxicating beverage had been kept, (he must drink the same) for five days.

A Soma-sacrificer, who has (unawares) smelt the breath of a man who had been drinking spirituous liquor, must plunge into water, (suppress his breath) and mutter the Aghamarshana three times. and eat clarified butter afterwards.
For eating (designedly) the flesh of an ass, of a camel, or of a crow, he must perform the Kândrâyana penance.
Likewise, for eating (knowingly) the flesh of an unknown (beast or bird), meat kept in a slaughterhouse, and dried meat.
For eating (unawares) the flesh of carnivorous beasts; (tigers- and others), or birds (hawks and others), he must perform the Taptakrikkhra.

For (knowingly) eating a sparrow, or (the heron called) Plava, or a Brâhmanî duck, or a Hamsa, or the (wild cock called) Raggudâla, or a Sârasa crane, or a Dâtyûha, or a male or female parrot, or a crane, or a heron, or a cuckoo, or a wagtail, he must fast for three days.
Likewise, for eating (unawares the flesh of) animals whose hoof is not cloven (such as horses),or of animals having a double row of teeth (such as the Rohita deer).
For eating (unawares) the flesh of any bird, excepting the francoline partridge, the Kâpiñgala, the (quail called) Lâvaka, the peahen, and the peacock, (he must fast) for a day and a night.
For eating (knowingly) insects (ants and others), he must drink for one day (water in which the plant) Brahmasuvarkalâ (has been boiled).
For eating (unawares) the flesh of dogs, he must perform the same penance.
For eating (unawares the mushroom called) Khattrâka, or (the mushroom called) Kavaka, he must perform the Sântapana penance.

For eating (unawares) stale food, other than a mess prepared with barley (such as cakes), or with wheat (such as, gruel), or with milk (boiled with rice, or mixed with coagulated milk, or otherwise dressed), and dishes sprinkled with fat (such as clarified butter), sour gruel, and sweetmeats, he must fast (for one day).
Likewise, (for eating unawares) the juice flowing from an incision in a tree, (plants raised in) unclean substances (such as excrements and the like), and the red exudation of trees.

Also, (for eating unawares) the root of the water-lily; (and for eating) rice boiled with sesamum. or with beans, Samyâva, rice boiled in milk with sugar, pastry, Sashkulî (cakes), or food destined forthe gods, if those dishes have not been announced to the gods first; and (for eating) food destined for burnt-oblations.
Also, for tasting the milk of any animal, save the milk of cows, goats, and buffalos (and for tasting any eatables made of such milk).
Also, (for tasting the milk) of those animals (cows and the rest) within ten days after their giving birth to a young one.
And (for tasting) the milk of a cow whose milk flows of itself, of one that has just taken the bull, or of one whose calf is dead.
And (for tasting the milk of a cow) that has been feeding upon ordures.
And (for tasting) any such food as has turned sour (but not that which is sour by nature, like sorrel), except sour milk (and what is made with it).
A student, who partakes (unawares) of a Srâddha repast, must fast for three days.
And he must remain in water for a whole day (afterwards).
If he eats honey or meat (at any time), he must perform the Prâgâpatya penance.
If any one eats (unawares) the leavings of thefood of a cat, of a crow, of an ichneumon, or of a rat, he must drink water in which the Brahmasuvarkalâ plant has been boiled.
For eating (unawares) what has been left by a dog, he must fast for one day, and drink Pañkagavya (afterwards).
For tasting (knowingly) the excrements of five-toed animals (excepting human excrements), he must (fast) for seven days (and drink Pañkagavya on the eighth).
If one (not a student) eats (unawares) of a Srâddha repast consisting of raw food, he must subsist on milk for seven days.
If a Brâhmana eats what has been left by a Sûdra, (he must also subsist on milk) for seven days.
If he eats what has been left by a Vaisya, (he must subsist upon milk) for five days.
If he eats what has been left by a Kshatriya, (he must subsist upon milk) for three days.
If he eats what has been left by another Brâhmana, (he must subsist upon milk) for one day.
If a Kshatriya eats what has been left by a Sûdra, (he must undergo the same penance) for five days.
If he eats what has been left by a Vaisya, (he must undergo it) for three days;
And so must a Vaisya, if he eats what has been left by a Sûdra.
For (knowingly) eating (undressed) food, which has been left by a Kandâla (or Svapaka or other member of the seven lowest castes), he must fast for three days.
For (unawares) eating dressed food (left by such), the Parâka penance is ordained.

Let no Brâhmana ever eat (the flesh of) beasts which has not been consecrated with Mantras; but if it has been consecrated with Mantras, he may eat it, following the eternal rule (laid down in the Veda).

As many hairs as the beast has, which he has slain in this world, for so many days will the killer of a beast for other purposes than a (Srauta or Smârta) sacrifice, suffer terrible pangs in this world and in the next.

It is for sacrifices that beasts have been created by the Self-existent (Brahman) himself. Sacrificing causes the whole universe to prosper; therefore is the slaughter (of beasts) for a sacrifice no slaughter.
The sin of him who kills deer for the sake of gain, is not so great (and visited less heavily) in the world to come, than the sin of him who eats meat which has not been offered to the gods.

Plants, cattle, trees, amphibious animals, and birds, which have been destroyed for the purposes of sacrifice, obtain exaltation in another existence (in which they are born as Gandharvas, or other beings of a high rank).
When honouring a guest, at a sacrifice, or when worshipping the manes, or the gods, a man may slay cattle, but not otherwise on any account.

That twice-born man who, knowing the exact truth (promulgated) in the Veda, slays cattle for the sacrifices (ordained in the Veda), will convey himself and the cattle (slain by him) to a blissful abode.

A self-controlled man of a twice-born caste, whether he be a householder, or be dwelling with his spiritual teacher, or in the forest, must never slay an animal in opposition to the precepts of the Veda, even in cases of distress.

That slaughter which is in accordance with the precepts of the Veda, and has been fixed for this world of movable and immovable creatures, should be considered as no slaughter at all; because it is from the Veda that law shines forth.
He who hurts animals that do not hurt any one, merely in order to afford pleasure to himself, will never obtain happiness, whether living or dead.
He who gives no living creature intentionally the pain of confining or killing (or hurting) it, from benevolence towards all (creatures), will enjoy everlasting happiness.
Whatever he thinks of, whatever he strives for, and whatever he desires in his heart, all that is easily obtained by him who does not injure any created being.
Meat cannot be obtained without injuring ananimal, and the murder of animals excludes the murderer from heaven, therefore must meat be avoided.
Reflecting upon the origin of flesh and upon the (sin of) hurting or confining animated creatures, he must abstain from animal food of any kind.
He who transgresses not the law and eats not flesh like a Pisâka, is beloved by men and remains free from disease.

He who gives his consent to the killing of an animal, he who cuts it up, he who kills it, the purchaser and the seller, he who prepares it, he who serves it up, and he who eats it, all these are denominated slaughterers of an animal.
There is no greater sinner than he who, without giving their share to the manes and to the gods, wants to increase his own flesh with the flesh of another creature.
Those two, he who performs a horse-sacrifice annually for a hundred years and he who does not eat meat, shall both obtain the same recompense for their virtue.
By eating (wild rice or other) sacred fruits or roots, and by living upon such grains as are the food of hermits, a man does not reap so high a reward as by avoiding meat
(An eater of flesh must say within himself), Me he (mâm sa) will eat in the next world, whoseflesh I am tasting here. This, say the learned, is the derivation of the word flesh (mâmsa).
He who has stolen the gold (of a Brâhmana), must bring a club to the king, proclaiming his deed.
Whether the king kills him with it, or dismisses him unhurt, he is purified.
Or (in case he committed the theft unawares), he must perform the Mahâvrata for twelve years.
He who appropriates (knowingly) a deposit, (must perform the same penance.)
He who steals (knowingly) grain or valuable objects, (or prepared food belonging to a Brâhmana,) (must perform) the Krikkhra for a year.
For stealing male or female slaves (not belonging to a Brâhmana, and for seizing) a well or pool (actually containing water), or a field, the Kândrâyana (penance must be performed).
(For stealing) articles of small value (such as tin or lead, not exceeding twenty-five Panas in value), the Sântapana (penance must be performed).
(For stealing) sweetmeats, (rice or other) food,(milk or other) drinks, a bed, a seat, flowers, roots, or fruit, drinking Pañkagavya (is ordained as penance).
(For stealing) grass, firewood, trees, rice in the husk, sugar, clothes, skins, or flesh, the thief must fast for three days.
(For stealing knowingly) precious stones, pearls or coral, copper, silver, iron, or white copper. he must eat grain separated from the husk for twelve days.
For stealing (unawares) cotton, silk, wool or other (stuffs), he must subsist for three days upon milk.
For stealing two-hoofed or one-hoofed animals, he must fast for three days.
For stealing birds, or perfumes, or medicinal herbs, or cords, or basket-work, he must fast for one day.
Though a thief may have restored to the owner the stolen property (either openly or) in some indirect manner, he must still perform a penance, in order to purify himself from guilt.
Whatever a man takes from others, unchecked (by the dictates of religion), of that will he be bereft in every future birth.
Because life, religious merit, and pleasure depend upon wealth, therefore let a man take care not to injure the wealth (of others by robbing them) by any means.
Among those two, he who injures animal life, and be who injures wealth, the one who injures wealth shall incur the heavier penalty.
One who has (unawares) had illicit sexual intercourse, must perform the Prâgâpatya penance for a year, according to the rule of the Mahâvrata, clad in a garment of bark, and living in a forest.
The same (penance is ordained) for sexual intercourse with the wife of another man (who belongs to his own caste, but is no Guru of his).
For intercourse with a cow, the Govrata (must be performed).

For intercourse with a man, for unnatural crimes with a woman, (for wasting his manhood) in the air, (for intercourse with a woman) in water, by day, or in a go-cart, he must bathe dressed in his clothes.
By intercourse (knowingly) with a Kandâla woman, he becomes her equal in caste.
For intercourse unawares with such, he must perform the Kândrâyana twice.
For intercourse (knowingly) with cattle (other) than cows) or with a public prostitute, (he must perform) the Prâgâpatya penance.
A woman who has committed adultery once,must perform that penance which has been prescribed for an adulterer.
That guilt which a Brâhmana incurs by intercourse with a Kandâla woman one night, he can only remove by subsisting upon alms, and constantly repeating (the Gâyatrî) for three years.
If a man associates with one guilty of a crime, he must perform the same penance as he.
A Brâhmana who has drunk water from a well in which a five-toed animal has perished, or which has been defiled in the highest degree, must fast for three days.
A Kshatriya (must fast) for two days (in the same case).
A Vaisya (must fast) for one day (and one night).
A Sûdra (must fast) for a night only.
And all (the former, but not a Sûdra) must drink Pañkagavya, when their penance has been completed.
If a Sûdra drinks Pañkagavya, or if a Brâhmana drinks spirituous liquor, they both go to the hell called Mahâraurava.
If a man has not connection with his wife in the natural season, unless it be on the days of the full and new moon, or because she is ill, he must fast for three days.
A false witness must perform the penance ordained for killing a Brâhmana.
He who has (unawares) voided excrements without water (being near), must bathe in his clothes, pronounce the 'great words,' and offer a burnt-oblation.
One who has been surprised asleep by the sun rising or setting, must bathe in his clothes and mutter the Gâyatrî one hundred -and eight times.
He who has been bitten by a dog, a jackal, a tame pig, an ass, an ape, a crow, or a public prostitute, shall approach a river and (standing in it, shall) stop his breath sixteen times.

One who forgets the Vedic texts which he has studied, or who forsakes the sacred fires, must subsist upon alms for a year, bathing at the tree Savanas  an ungrateful man, one who buys or sells with false weights, and one who deprives Brâhmanas of their livelihood (by robbing them of a grant made to them by the king or private persons, or by other bad practices), all those persons must subsist upon alms for a year.

An unmarried elder brother whose younger brother is married, a younger brother married before the elder, an unmarried elder sister whose younger sister is married, the relative who gives such a damsel in marriage, and the priest who officiates at such a marriage, must perform the Kândrâyana.
, He who sells living beings, land, religious merit (obtained by a sacrifice or otherwise), or Soma, must perform the Taptakrikkhra.

He who sells fresh ginger, (edible) plants (such as rice or barley), perfumes, flowers, fruits, roots, skins, canes, (winnowing baskets or fans and the like) made of split bamboo, chaff, potsherds, hair, ashes, bone, cow-milk or curds, oil-cakes, sesamum, or oil, must perform the Prâgâpatya.

He who sells the fruit of the Sleshmâtaka tree, lac, bees-wax, shells, mother-of-pearl, tin, lead, iron, copper, or, (sacrificial) vessels made of the horn of the rhinoceros, must perform the Kândrâyana.
He who sells dyed cloth, tin, preciousstones, perfumes, sugar, honey, liquids or condiments (other than sugar, salt, and the like), or wool, must fast for three days.
He who sells meat, salt, lac, or milk, must perform the Kândrâyana.
And all those persons  must be initiated a second time.
He who has been riding (voluntarily) upon a camel, or upon an ass, and he who has (purposely) bathed, or slept, or eaten, quite naked, must stop his breath three times.

By muttering attentively the Gâyatrî three thousand times, (by dwelling) upon the pasture of cows, (and) by subsisting on milk for a month, he becomes free from the sin of accepting unlawful presents.

He who has (knowingly) offered a sacrifice for an unworthy person (such as a low-caste person, or an outcast), he who has performed the funeral rites for a stranger, he who has practised magic rites (in order to destroy an enemy), and he who has performed a sacrifice of the kind called Ahîna, (all those persons) may rid themselves of theirsins by performing three Krikkhra (Prâgâpatya) penances.

Those twice-born men, by whom the Gâyatrî has not been repeated (and the other initiatory ceremonies performed), as the law directs, must be made to perform three (Prâgâpatya) penances and must be initiated according to custom.
Those twice-born men who are anxious to make an atonement for having committed an illegal act, or for having neglected the study of the Veda, must be made to perform the same penance.

Those Brâhmanas who have acquired property by base acts (such as living by the occupations of a lower caste, or accepting unlawful presents) become free from sin by relinquishing it, and by muttering (Veda texts) and practising austerities.
For omitting one of the regular acts enjoined in the revealed (and traditional) law, and for a breach of the rules laid down for a Snâtaka, a fast is ordained as atonement.

For attacking a Brâhmana (by raising a stick or a weapon against him), the Krikkhra (Prâgâpatya) penance must be performed; for striking him, the Atikrikkhra; and for fetching blood from him, the Krikkhrâtikrikkhra.
With sinners, who have not expiated their crime, let a man not transact business of any kind. But a man who knows the law must not blame (or shun) those who have expiated it.

Let him not, however, live (or have any intercourse) with those who have killed children, or with ungrateful persons, or with those who have slain one come for protection, or a woman, even though such sinners may have obtained their absolution, as directed by the law.
(An old man) who has passed his eightieth year, a youth under the age of sixteen, women, and sick persons have only to perform half of every penance.

In order to remove those sins for which no particular mode of expiation has been mentioned, penances must be prescribed, which shall be in accordance with the ability of the offender, and with the heaviness of his offence.
Now follow the penances for secret sins.

The killer of a Brâhmana is purified, if, having approached a river (and bathed in it), he restrains his breath sixteen times, and takes only one meal, consisting of food fit for offerings, each day, for a month.
At the end of this rite he must give a milch cow.
By performing the same rite and by muttering (while standing in the water) the Aghamarshana (instead of stopping his breath), a drinker of spirituous liquor becomes free from sin.
(By performing the same rite and) muttering the Gâyatrî one thousand and ten times (each day), a stealer of gold becomes free from guilt.
One who has connection with a Guru's wife (becomes free from sin) by fasting for three days and muttering the Purushasûkta and (at the same time) offering a burnt-oblation.
Even as the horse-sacrifice, the king of sacrifices, removes all sin, the hymn of Aghamarshana likewise removes all sin.
Let a twice-born man stop his breath, in order to rid himself of all sin; all sins committed by atwice-born man may be removed by repeated Prânâyâmas.

It is called a Prânâyâma, if a man, stopping the breath (which comes from the mouth and from the nostrils), recites the Gâyatrî three times, together with the Vyâhritis ('words'), with the sacred syllable Om, and with the (text called) Siras.

The lord of creatures (Brahman) has milked out from the three Vedas the letter A, the letter U, and the letter M (of which the sacred syllable Om is composed), and (the three sacred words) Bhûh, Bhuvah, Svah (earth, the atmosphere, and heaven).

The lord of creatures, the supreme deity, has also milked out from the three Vedas successively the three verses of the sacred stanza which begins with the word 'tad,' and is called Sâvitrî (or Gâyatrî).

By muttering, every morning and evening, that syllable and that stanza, preceded by the three 'words,' a Brâhmana will obtain that religious merit which the (study of the) Veda confers, just as if he had actually studied the Veda.

By repeating those three (Om, the 'words,' and the Gâyatrî every day) for a month out of the village, a thousand times, a twice-born man is purified even from a mortal sin, as a snake (is freed) from its withered skin.
Any member of the Brâhmana, Kshatriya, or Vaisya castes, who does not know those three texts,or fails to recite them in the proper season, meets with reproach among the virtuous.
The three imperishable 'great words,' preceded by the syllable Om, and the Gâyatrî consisting of three divisions, have to be recognised as the mouth (or beginning) of the Veda.

He who repeats that stanza (preceded by the syllable Om and the three 'words') carefully every day for three years, will be absorbed in the highest Brahman after death, move as freely as air, and become as pure as air.
The monosyllable (Om) is the highest Brahman, the stoppings of the breath are the best of austerities, but nothing is more exalted than the Gâyatrî; (declaring the) truth is better than silence.

All religious acts ordained in the Veda, (whether) consisting in burnt-oblations or sacrifices (or alms-giving or other pious observances), perish (after the merit obtained by them has been exhausted); but the syllable Om (akshara) must be known to be imperishable (akshara), as it is identical with Brahman, the lord of creatures.

The act of reciting (the syllable Om, the 'words,' and the Gâyatrî) is ten times better than the (Gyotishtoma or other) sacrifices prescribed (by the Veda); it is a hundred times better when muttered in a low voice; it is a thousand times better when repeated mentally only.

The four Pâkayagñas (small or domesticofferings), together with the sacrifices prescribed (in the Veda), though all united, are not equal to a sixteenth part of the sacrifice performed by reciting (those sacred prayers).

A Brâhmana may beyond doubt obtain final emancipation by solely repeating (those prayers), whether he perform any other religious observance or no; one who is benevolent towards all creatures (and does not slay them for sacrifices) is justly, called a Brâhmana (or one united to Brahman).
Now then follow the purifying Mantras from all the Vedas.
By muttering them, or reciting them at a burnt-oblation, the twice-born are purified from their sins. (They are as follows:)
The Aghamarshana;
The Devakrita;
The Suddhavatîs;
The Taratsamandîya;
The Kûshmândîs;
The Pâvamânîs;
The Durgâsâvitrî;
The Atishangas;
The Padastobhas;
The Vyâhriti Sâmans.;
The Bhârundas;
The Kandrasâman;
Thetwo Sâmans called Purushavrata;
The Ablinga;
The Bârhaspatya;
The Gosûkta;
The Âsvasûkta;
The two Sâmans called Kandrasûkta;
The Satarudriya;
The Atharvasiras;
The Trisuparna;
The Mahâvrata;
The Nârâyanîya;
And the Purushasûkta;;

The three Âgyadohas, the Rathantara, the Agnivrata, the Vâmadevya, and the Brihatsâman, properly chanted, purify man from sin; and if he wishes he may obtain through them recollection of his existence in a former life.
Now (the following persons) must be avoided:
Vrâtyas (i. e. those for whom the ceremony of initiation has not been performed)
Outcasts;
Descendants within the third degree' of an outcast mother or father, if they (or their outcast ancestors) have not been purified (by a penance).
(As a rule) the food of all such persons must not be eaten, nor gifts be accepted from them,.
He must avoid accepting repeated gifts from those whose presents must not be accepted.
By accepting such gifts, Brâhmanas lose their divine lustre.
And he who, not knowing the law regarding acceptance of gifts, accepts (illicit) gifts, sinks, to hell together with the giver.
He who, being worthy to receive gifts, does not accept them, obtains that world which is destined for the liberal-minded (after death).
Firewood, water, roots, fruits, protection, meat, honey, a bed, a seat, a house, flowers, sourmilk, and vegetables he must not disdain to accept when they are offered to him.

Even if an offender (but not a mortal sinner) has beckoned and offered alms to him, which had been brought previously for the purpose, the lord of creatures has declared that they may be accepted from him.
Neither will the manes eat (his funeral oblations offered to them) for fifteen years, nor will the fire convey his burnt-offerings (to the gods) if he rejects such alms.

If he wishes to provide for his (parents or other) Gurus or for (his wife or other) such persons as he is bound to maintain, or if he wants to worship the manes or the gods, he may accept gifts from any one; but he must not satisfy himself with them.
But even in those cases, and though he be worthy to receive presents, let him not accept them from a dissolute woman, from a eunuch, from an outcast, or from an enemy.

And if his parents are dead, or if he is living apart from them in a house of his own, he must never, while seeking to obtain food for himself, accept alms from any other persons but those who are of respectable descent (and belong to a twice-born caste).

One who ploughs the ground for half the crop (and gives the other half to the king or a private person, who is the owner), a friend of the family, a (house-)slave, a herdsman, a barber, andone who announces himself (with the words 'I am your slave'): the food of all such may be eaten, although they are Sûdras.
The property of householders is of three kinds:
White, mottled, and black.
By those obsequies which a man performs with white property, he causes (his departed ancestor) to be born again as a god.
By performing them with mottled property, he causes him to be born as a man.
By performing them with black property, he causes him to be born as an animal.
What has been acquired by the mode of livelihood of their own caste, by members of any caste, is called 'white.'
What has been acquired by the mode of livelihood of the caste next below in order to their own, is called 'mottled.'
What has been acquired by the mode of livelihood of a caste by two or more degrees lower than their own, is called 'black.'
What has been inherited, friendly gifts, andthe dowry of a wife, that is called white property, for members of any caste indiscriminately.

What has been acquired as a bribe, as a fee (for crossing a river and the like, or for a bride, &c.), or by the sale of forbidden articles (such as lac, or salt), or as a return for a benefit conferred, is denoted 'mottled wealth.'

What has been acquired by servile attendance, by gambling, by thieving, by begging, by deceit (as if a man says that he wants a present for another and takes it himself, or by forging gold or other metals), by robbery, or by fraud (as if a man shows one thing to a purchaser and delivers another to him instead), is called 'black property.'
Whatever a man may do (in this world) with anything (he has, whether white, mottled, or black property) he will get his reward accordingly; both in the next world and in this.
A householder must perform the Pâkayagñas(small or domestic offerings) in the fire kindled at the time of marriage.
He must offer the Agnihotra (or daily oblations of clarified butter) every morning and evening (in the Tretâ fires).
He must offer burnt-oblations to the gods (in case the Agnihotra cannot be performed).
Let him offer the two Darsapurnamâsas on the days of conjunction and opposition of the sunand moon.
Once in each half of the year, (at the two solstices, let him offer) the Pasubandha (animal sacrifice).
In autumn and summer let him offer the Âgrayana (oblation of first-fruits);
Or when rice and barley are ripening (in winter and spring).
He who has a sufficient supply of food for more than three years (shall perform the Soma-sacrifice).
(He shall perform) the Soma-sacrifice once a year (in spring).
If he has not wealth (sufficient to defray the expenses of the Pasubandha, Soma, Kâturmâsya, and other Srauta sacrifices), he shall perform the Ishti Vaisvânarî.
Let him not make an offering of food obtained as alms from a Sûdra.
If he has begged articles for a sacrifice (and obtained them), let him employ them all for that purpose (and never for himself).
Every evening and morning let him offer up the Vaisvadeva;
And let him give alms to an Ascetic (afterwards).
For giving alms and showing due honour to the recipient (by pouring water on his hands both before and afterwards) he obtains the same reward as for giving a cow.
If there is no ascetic (or other person worthy to receive alms), he must give a mouthful to cows;
Or he must cast it into fire.
If there is food in the house, he must not reject a mendicant, (who arrives) after he has taken his meal himself.
A householder has five places where animals are liable to be destroyed: his wooden mortar, his slab to grind wheat or condiments upon, his fireplace, his water-pot, and his broom.

For the sake of expiating offences committed (by ignorantly destroying life) in those places, he must perform the (five) sacrifices addressed to the Veda, to the gods, to all created beings (or 'to the goblins'), to the manes, and to men.
Privately reciting (and teaching) the Veda is the sacrifice addressed to the Veda.
The regular burnt-oblation (Vaisvadeva) is the sacrifice addressed to the gods.
The Pitritarpana (refreshing the manes with food and water) is the sacrifice addressed to the manes.
The Bali-offering is the sacrifice addressed to all creatures (or 'to the goblins').
The sacrifice addressed to men consists in honouring a guest.
He who does not give their share to these five, the gods, his guests, (his wife and children and others,) whom he is bound to maintain, his manes, and himself, is not alive, though he breathes.

These (three), the student, the hermit, and the ascetic, derive their existence from the order of householders; therefore must a householder not treat them with disdain, when they have arrived (at his house at the proper time for begging alms).
The householder offers sacrifices, the householder practises austerities, the householder distributes gifts; therefore is the order of householders, the first of all.
The Rishis, the manes, the gods, all creatures (dogs, &c.), and guests beg householders for support; therefore is the order of householders the best of all.

If a householder is intent upon pursuing the three objects of life (virtue, love, and wealth), upon constantly distributing presents of food, upon worshipping the gods, upon honouring the Brâhmanas, upon discharging his duty of privately reciting (and teaching) the Veda, and upon refreshing the manes (with oblations of balls of rice, water, and the like), he will attain the world of Indra.
In (the last watch of the night, which is called)the hour sacred to Brahman, let him rise and void his excrements.
By night (let him void them) facing the south, by day and during either twilight (let him void them) facing the north.
(He must) not (void them) on earth which has not been previously covered (with grass and the like);
Nor on a ploughed field;
Nor in the shade of a tree (fit to be used for sacrifices);
Nor on barren soil;
Nor on a spot abounding in fresh grass;
Nor where there are worms or insects;
Nor in a ditch (or hole, or upon the roots of a tree);
Nor on an ant-hill;
Nor on a path;
Nor on a public road;
Nor in a place previously defiled by another person;
Nor in a garden;
Nor in the vicinity of a garden or of (a reservoir of) water;
Nor on ashes;
Nor on coal;
Nor oncow-dung;
Nor in a fold for cattle;
Nor in the air;
Nor in water;
Nor facing the wind, or fire, or the moon, or the sun, or a woman, or a (father or other) Guru, or a Brâhmana;
Nor without having enveloped his head;

Having cleaned his hindparts with a clod of earth, or with a brick, (or with wood or grass,) and seizing his organ (with his left, after having removed his garment), he must rise and clean himself with water and earth (previously) fetched for the purpose, so as to remove the smell and the filth.
The organ must once be cleaned with earth, the hindparts three times, the one hand (the left) ten times, both hands together seven times, and both feet together three times.
Such is the purification ordained for householders; it is double for students treble for hermits; and quadruple for ascetics.
A householder must not use Palâsa-wood for cleaning his teeth.
Nor (must he use the twigs of) the Sleshmântaka(or Selu) plant, nor of the soap plant, nor of the Vibhîtaka (or Kalidruma) tree, nor of the Dhava plant, nor of the Dhâmani tree (for that purpose).
Nor (the twigs of) the Bandhûka (or Bandhugîvaka) plant, nor of the Nirgundî shrub, nor of theS
Nor (the twigs of) the Kovidâra (Yugapattraka) Samî, Pîlu (Gudaphala), Pippala (holy fig-tree), Inguda, or Guggula trees;
Nor (the twigs of) the Pâribhâdraka (Sakrapâdapa), or tamarind, or Mokaka, or Semul trees, nor those of the hemp plant;
Nor sweet plants (such as liquorice sticks):
Nor sour plants (such as Âmlikâs);
Nor twigs that have withered on the stem;
Nor perforated (or otherwise faulty) wood;
Nor stinking wood;
Nor smooth wood;
He must not (use the sticks) facing the south or west.
He must use them facing the north or east;

He may use (the twigs of) the banyan or Asana trees, or of the Arka plant, or of the Khadira, or Karañga, or Badara (jujube), or Sal, or Nimb trees, or of the Arimeda, shrub, or of the Apâmârga or Malatî plants, or of the Kakubha or Bèl trees;
Or of the Kashâya tree, or of the Tikta or Katuka plants.

Before sunrise let him silently clean his teeth with a stick, which must be as thick as the top of the little finger, provided with one end that may be chewed (or 'with a brush'), and twelve Angulas long.
Having washed and used the stick for cleaning the teeth, he must take care to leave it in a clean place; he must never make use of it on the day of new moon (or on the day of full moon).
The part at the root of the little finger of a twice-born man is called the Tîrtha sacred to Pragâpati.
The part at the root of the thumb is called the Tîrtha sacred to Brahman.
The part at the tops of the fingers is called the Tîrtha sacred to the gods.
The part at the root of the forefinger is called the Tîrtha sacred to the manes.

Let him sip water, which has not been put to the fire and is free from foam (and bubbles), which has not been poured out by a Sûdra (or other uninitiated person), or by a man who has one hand only, and which has no saline flavour; and (let him sip it) in a clean place, duly seated, placing (his right hand) between his knees, facing the east or the north (or, the north-east), attentively regarding the water, and in a cheerful mood.
Let him sip water thrice with the Tîrtha sacredto Brahman (or with the Tîrthas sacred to the gods and to Pragipati respectively).
Let him wipe his lips twice (with the root of his thumb).
Let him touch the cavities (above his navel), his head, and his breast with water.

By water which reaches either their heart, or their throat, or their palate respectively, members of the three twice-born castes are purified each in his turn; a woman and a Sûdra are purified by water which has once touched their palate.
In order to obtain wealth and for the sake of security he shall apply to a lord.
He must not travel alone;
Nor with wicked companions;
Nor with Sûdras;
Nor with enemies;
Nor too early in the morning;
Nor too late in the evening;
Nor in the twilight;
Nor in too great a hurry;
Nor at night
Nor (let him travel) without cessation with (horses or other) beasts of draught that are quite young, diseased, or (otherwise) afflicted;
Nor with such as are deficient in limb;
Nor with weak ones;
Nor with young bulls;
Nor with untrained animals.
He must not appease his hunger and allay his thirst without having first given grass and water to the animals.
He must not stop at a place where four ways meet;
Nor at night at the root of a tree:
Nor in an empty house;
Nor upon a meadow;
Nor in a stable;
Nor (must he stand) on hair, on the husks of grain, on potsherds, on bones, on ashes, or coal;
Nor on seeds of the cotton plant.
When he passes by a place where four ways meet, let him turn his right side towards it.
And let him do the same in passing by the image of a deity;
And in passing by well-known large trees.

After having seen a fire, or a Brâhmana (with his turban on), or a public prostitute, or a jar filled (with water), or a looking-glass, or an umbrella, or a flag, or a banner, or a Bèl tree, or a lid (or platter), or a palace built in the shape of a certain diagram (or in the form of a quadrangle without a western gate);
Or a fan, or a chowrie, or a horse, or an elephant, or a goat, or a cow (having a calf), or sour milk, or milk, or honey, or white mustard;
Or a lute, or sandal-wood, or a weapon, or fresh cow-dung, or fruit, or a flower, or a fresh pot-herb, or Gorokanâ, or blades of Dûrvâ grass;
Or a turban, or ornaments, or jewels, or gold, or silver, or clothes, or a seat, or a vehicle, or (raw) meat;

Or a golden vase, or cultivated land which is being carried away (by a stream), or a single (bull or other) piece of cattle tied with a rope, or an unmarried damsel (clad in white), or a (boiled) fish, (let him turn his right side towards them and) go on.
Having seen one intoxicated, or insane, deformed, he must or turn back;
(Also, if he has seen) one who has vomited, or one who has been purged, or one who has had his head shorn, or one who wears all his hair tied in one knot, or a dwarf;
Or (if he has seen) one wearing a dress (of a reddish-yellow colour) dyed with Kashâya, or an ascetic, or one smeared (with ashes);
Or (if he has seen) oil, or sugar, or dry cow-dung, or fire-wood, or grass (other than Kusa or Dûrvâ grass), or Palâsa (and other leaves, other than betel leaves), ashes, or coal;
Or (if he has seen) salt, or a eunuch, or (the spirituous liquor called) Âsava, or an impotent man, or cotton cloth, or a rope, or an iron chain for the feet, or a person with dishevelled hair.
(If he sees), while about to begin a journey, a lute, or sandal-wood, or fresh pot-herbs, or a turban, or an Ornament, or an unmarried damsel, he must praise them.

He must not (knowingly) step on (or step over, or stand on) the shade of the image of a deity, of a (learned) Brâhmana, of a spiritual teacher, of a brown (bull or other animal), or of one by whom the initiatory ceremony at a Soma-sacrifice has been performed.
Nor (must he step) on anything spat out or vomited, nor on blood, nor on fæces or urine, nor on water used for ablutions.
He must not step over a rope to which a calf (or a cow) is tied.
He must not walk quickly in the rain.
He must not cross a river without need;
Nor without having previously offered an oblation of water to the gods and to the manes;
Nor (swimming) with his arms;
Nor in a leaky vessel.
He must not stand on the bank (of a river).
He must not gaze into a pool.
He must not cross it (by swimming through it, or in any other way).

Way must be made for an aged man, for one carrying a burden, for a king, for a Snâtaka (of any of the three kinds), for a woman, for a sick person, for a bridegroom, and for one riding in a carriage. Among those, should they all meet, a king must behonoured by the rest (excepting the Snâtaka); but the king himself must show honour to a Snâtaka.
He must not bathe in another man's pool;
In cases of distress (if there is no other water at hand) he may bathe (in another man's pool), after having offered up five (or seven, or four) lumps of clay and (three jars with) water.
(He must not bathe) during an indigestion;
Nor while he is afflicted (with a fever or other illness);
Nor without his clothes;
Nor at night;
Unless it be during an eclipse;
Nor in the twilight.
, He must bathe early in the morning, when he beholds the east reddening with the rays of the (rising) sun.
After having bathed, he must not shake his head (in order to remove the water from his hair);
And he must not dry his limbs (with his hand or with a cloth);
Nor must he touch any oily substance.
He must not put on again the garment which he wore before, without its having been washed.
After having bathed, he must cover with his head a turban and put on two garments washed (by himself).
He must not converse, (after having bathed,) with barbarians, low-caste persons, or outcasts.
He must bathe in cascades, ponds dug by the gods, and lakes.

Stagnant water is more pure (and purifies more effectually) than water taken out (of a well or the like); the water of a spring is more pure than that of a tank; the water of a river is more pure than the former; water collected by (Vasishtha or some other) devout sage is even more pure; but the water of the Ganges is the purest of all.

After having removed the dirt by means of earth and water, and after having dived under water and returned (to the bank of the river), he must address the bathing-place with the three Mantras (beginning with the words), 'Ye waters are,'with the four Mantras (beginning with the words),'The golden-coloured (waters),' and with (the one Mantra beginning with the words), 'Carry away (all), that, O ye waters.'
Then he must dive underwater and mutter the Aghamarshana three times;
Or (he must mutter three times the Mantra which begins with the words), 'That most exalted step of Vishnu;'
Or the Drupadâ Sâvitrî (which begins with the words, 'Like one released from a post);
Or the Anuvâka (which begins with the words), 'They get their minds ready;'
Or the Purushasûkta.
After having bathed, he must feed the gods and the manes, while standing in the water with his wet clothes on.
If (being unable to remain in water after having bathed) he has changed his dress, (he must feed the gods and the manes,) after having crossed the bathing-place (and reached the bank).
(But) he must not wring his bathing-dress till he has satisfied the gods and the manes.;
After having bathed and sipped water, he must sip water (once more) according to the rule.
He must offer (sixteen) flowers to Purusha,while muttering the Purushasûkta, one with each verse.
Afterwards (he must offer) a libation of water.
He must first offer one to the gods with the Tîrtha sacred to the gods.
Then he must offer an other to the manes with the Tîrtha sacred to the manes.
In offering the latter he must first of all feed (the manes of) his next of kin (such as his father, mother, maternal grandfather, uncles, brothers, &c.)
After that (he must feed) his relatives (such as a sister's son, a father-in-law, a brother-in-law, &c.) and distant kinsmen (such as the sons of his father's sisters and of his mother's sisters).
Then (he must feed) his (deceased) friends.
According, to the above rule he must bathe every day.
After having bathed, he must mutter as many purifying Mantras as possible.
And he must mutter the Gâyatrî even more often (than other Mantras);
And the Purushasûkta.
There is nothing more sublime than those two (prayers).
One who has bathed is thereby entitled to perform the offerings to the Visvedevâs and to the manes, to mutter sacred texts, and to exercise the duty of hospitality, as prescribed by law.
Distress and misfortune, bad dreams and evil thoughts are taken from him even who only sprinkles himself with water (no matter from where it comes): that is the law.
He who regularly takes the prescribed bath (every morning), does not experience the tortures of Yama's hell. By the regular bath criminals even obtain their absolution.

Now then, after having duly bathed, and duly washed his hands and feet, and duly sipped water, he must worship Bhagavat Vâsudeva (Vishnu), who is without beginning and end, before an idol or on the sacrificial ground.

Having called up in his mind (Vishnu to life, with the Mantra), 'The two Asvins possess life, may they (give you life),'and having invited (Vishnu) with the Anuvâka (beginning with the words), 'They get their minds ready,' he must worship him with his knees, his hands, and his head.
With the three Mantras (beginning with the words), 'Ye waters are,' he must (fetch and) announce the Arghya (or water for washing the hands).
With the four Mantras (beginning with the words), 'The golden-coloured,' (he must fetch and announce) the water for washing the feet;
With (the one Mantra, beginning with the words), 'May the waters of the plain propitiate us,' the water which is to be sipped;
With (the one Mantra, beginning with the words), 'Carry away (all) that, O ye waters,' the water destined for the bath;
With (the four Mantras, beginning with the words, 'Proud) of the chariot, of the poles, the hero,' unguents and ornaments;
With (the one Mantra, beginning with the words), 'A youth, splendidly arrayed,' a garment;
With (the one Mantra, beginning with the word), 'Blooming,' a flower;
With (the one Mantra, beginning with thewords), 'Thou art murderous (dhûr), slay (dhûrva) (the slayer),' incense (dhûpa);
With (the one Mantra, beginning with the words), 'Thou art splendour and light,' a lamp;
With (the one Mantra, beginning with the words, 'I have praised) Dadhikrâvan,' a Madhuparka (honey-mixture);
With the eight Mantras (beginning with the word), 'Hiranyagarbha,' an offering of (other) eatables.

A chowrie, a fan, a looking-glass, an umbrella, a (palanquin or other) vehicle, and a (throne or other) seat, all these objects he must announce (and place before) the god (Vishnu), muttering the Gâyatrî (at the same time).
After having thus worshipped him, he must mutter the Purushasûkta. After that, he who wishes to obtain eternal bliss must make oblations of clarified butter, while reciting the same hymn.
He must not make an oblation to the gods or to the manes with water collected at night.
He must not give any other fragrant substance than sandal, or musk, or (fragrant) wood (of the odoriferous Devadâru tree), or camphor, or saffron, or the wood of the Gâtîphala tree;
Nor a garment dyed with indigo;
Nor an ornament made of factitious jewels or gold;
Nor (a flower) having a nasty odour;
Nor one that has no odour at all;
Nor one grown upon a thorny plant.
But he may give even a flower grown upon a thorny plant, if it is white and sweet-smelling.
He may give even a red flower, if it is saffron, or a water-flower (such as the red lotus).
(He must) not (give) any animal substance (such as claws or horns) for the incense.
(He must) not (give) anything but clarified butter or oil for the lamp.
(He must) not (give) forbidden food at the offering of eatables;
Nor the milk of goats or female buffalos, though it is lawful food (otherwise);
Nor the flesh of five-toed animals, of fishes, and of boars.

Fully prepared for the sacrifice and pure, he must announce (and offer up to Vishnu) all the oblations, with his mind fixed upon the deity, with a cheerful heart, and free from precipitation or anger.

After having swept the place around the (kitchen) fire, sprinkled it with water all around,strewed (Kusa grass) all around, and sprinkled (the latter) with water all around, he must take out of all dishes the uppermost part and offer it:
To Vâsudeva, to Sankarshana, to Pradyumna, to Aniruddha, to Purusha, to Satya, to Akyuta, to Vâsudeva.

Afterwards (he must offer twelve burnt-oblations) to Agni, to Soma, to Mitra, to Varuna, to Indra, to Indra and Agni united, to the Visvedevâs, to Pragâpati, to Anumati, to Dhanvantari, to Vâstoshpati, and to Agni Svishtakrit (the god of the fire who causes the proper performance of the sacrifice).
Then let him make a Bali-offering with that which has been left of the dishes.
To (the serpent demons) Taksha and Upataksha,
(Strewing the two Balis) on both sides of the fire, to the east of it (on the north-eastern side first, and on the south-eastern side afterwards).

(Then let him offer other seven Balis) to all (the seven Ishtakâs or goddesses of the bricks of the altar, also to the east of the fire, while pronouncing the Mantras), 'Thy name is Ambâ; thy name is Dulâ; thy name is Nitatnî (Nitatnir); thy name is Kupunîkâ (and so on).'

(He must offer four Balis with the Mantras), 'O Nandinî; O Subhagâ; O Sumangalî; O Bhadrankarî,' (placing the Balis) in the corners (beginning with the south-eastern corner and proceeding) towards the south.
(He must place two Balis), addressed to Sri Hiranyakesî and to the trees, near the firm pillar.
(He must place two Balis), addressed to Dharma and Adharma and to Mrityu, near the door.
(He must place one Bali), addressed to Varuna, in the water-jar.
(With the words, 'Adoration be) to Vishnu,' (he must place one Bali) in the mortar.
(With the words, 'Adoration be) to the Maruts,' (he must place one Bali) on the mill-stone.
(In the apartment) on the roof (let him place two Balis) addressed to Vaisrâvana (Kubera) the king, and to all created beings.
(With the words, 'Adoration be) to Indra and to Indra's ministers,' (he must place two Balis). in the eastern part (of the house).
(With the words, 'Adoration be) to Yama and to Yama's ministers,' (he must place two Balis) in the southern part..
(With the words, 'Adoration be) to Varuna and to Varuna's ministers,' (he must place two Balis) in the western part.
(With the words, 'Adoration be) to Soma and to Soma's ministers,' (let him place two Balis) in the northern part.
(With the words, 'Adoration be) to Brahman and to Brahman's ministers,' (let him place two Balis) in the centre (of the house).
(Let him throw) in the air (a Bali) addressed to Âkâsa (the air).
(With the words, 'Adoration be) to the goblins roaming by day,' (let him place a Bali) on the sacrificial ground.
(With the words, 'Adoration be to the goblins) roaming by night,' (let him offer a Bali in the same place at the Vaisvadeva which takes place) at night.

Afterwards he must offer upon blades of Kusa grass, having the points turned towards the south, balls of rice to his father, to his grandfather, and to his great-grandfather, to his mother, to his grandmother, and to his great-grandmother, proclaiming at the same time their name and race (and adding the word Svadhâ, 'reverence').
Along with the balls of rice let him give ointments, flowers, incense, eatables, and the like.
After having fetched a jar with water, let himcause a Brâhmana to say the benediction (and give him the jar).
(The share) of dogs, crows, and Svapakas let him strew upon the earth.
And let him give (a mouthful of food as) alms.
By honouring guests he obtains the highest reward.
Let him assiduously honour a guest who arrives in the evening (after the Vaisvadeva is over).
Let him not suffer a guest to stay at his house unfed.
As the Brâhmanas are lords over all other castes, and as a husband is lord over his wives, a guest is the lord of a householder.
By honouring a guest he obtains heaven.

(One who has arrived as) a guest and is obliged to turn home disappointed in his expectations, takes away from the man, to whose house he has come, his religious merit, and throws his own guilt upon him.
A Brâhmana who stays for one night only as a guest, is called atithi (a guest); because he does not stay for a long time, therefore is he termed atithi.
Let him not consider a Brâhmana fellow-villager or an acquaintance as his guest, though he has come to the house where his wife and his fires are.
But if a Kshatriya has come to his house in the way of a guest, let him hospitably entertain him also, to his heart's desire, after the Brâhmana guests have eaten.

Should a Vaisya or a Sûdra come to his house as guests, he must even give food to them (at the same time and) with his servants, and treat them with kindness (but not like guests in the proper sense of the term).

To (members of) other castes (such as Mûrdhâvasiktas) and to friends (or relatives or) other such persons, who have come to his house out of attachment, let him offer such food as happens to be there, to the best of his power, at the time when his wife takes her meal.
One recently married (but not yet delivered to her husband), an unmarried damsel, a sick woman, and a pregnant woman: to these let him give food unhesitatingly, even before his guests.
The foolish man who eats first himself, without having offered food to those (persons that have been mentioned), is not aware that he will himself be food (after death) for dogs and vultures.

After the Brâhmanas, (the Kshatriyas who have come as guests), the friends and relatives, (the parents and others) whom he is bound to maintain,(and the servants) have made their repast, let man and wife eat the leavings themselves.

Having shown honour to the gods, to the manes, to men, to those whom he is bound to maintain, and to the household deities (as well as to dogs, crows, and the rest), let a householder enjoy that which has been left.
He who cooks food for himself only, cats nothing but sin: for that alone is considered as fit food for the virtuous, which is left, after the (customary) oblations have been offered.
By the daily recitation of the Veda, by the Agnihotra, by sacrificing, and by austerity, a householder does not obtain such excellent places of abode (after death) as by honouring a guest.
Whether he arrives in the evening or in the morning, he must offer a seat and water to his guest, and food, to the best of his ability, after having shown him marks of honour as the law directs.
By giving (to a guest) shelter, a bed, ointments for his feet, and a lamp: for each of these gifts singly he reaps the same reward as for the gift of a cow.
He must not eat during an eclipse of the moon or of the sun.
He shall eat, after having previously bathed, when the eclipse is over.
If (the sun or moon) have set before the eclipse was over, he must bathe, and on the next day he may eat again, after having seen (the sun or moon rise),
A cow or a Brâhmana having met with a calamity, he must not eat on that day.
If the king has met with an accident, (he must not eat on that day).
An Agnihotrin, who is absent on a journey, must eat at that time of the day when the Agnihotra is supposed to be over.
He may also eat at that time of the day when the Vaisvadeva is supposed to be over.
On the days of new and full moon (he may eat at that time) when he supposes the sacrifice customary on those days to have been performed.
He must not eat during an indigestion;
Nor at midnight;
Nor at noon;
Nor in the twilight;
Nor dressed in wet clothes;
Nor without his upper garment;
Nor naked;
Nor in water (nor in a boat)
Nor lying stretched out on the back;
Nor sitting on a broken stool;
Nor reclining on a couch;
Nor from a broken dish;
Nor having placed the food on his lap;
Nor (having placed the food) upon the ground;
Nor from the palm of his hand.
That food which has been seasoned with salt (after having been cooked) he must not eat.
He must not abuse children (eating in the same row with him).
(He must) not (eat) dainties alone.
(He must) not (eat) substances from which the fat has been extracted.
, Nor (must he eat) roasted grain in the daytime.
At night (he must not eat) anything mixed with sesamum-seeds.
Nor (must he eat at night) sour milk or ground barley.
Nor (must he eat) the leaves of the mountain ebony, or of the banyan, or of the holy fig-tree, or of the hemp plant.
(He must) not (eat) without having first given to eat (to the gods and to the Brâhmanas); Nor without having made a burnt-offering first
Nor without having sprinkled his feet;
Nor without having sprinkled his hands and his face;
While having the remains of food en his mouth or hands, he must not take clarified butter.
Nor must he look at the moon, or at the sun, or at the stars (while unclean).
Nor must he touch his head (while unclean).
Nor must he recite the Veda (while unclean).
He must eat facing the east;
Or facing the south;
And after having honoured his food;
And cheerfully, adorned with a garland of flowers, and anointed with unguents.
He must not eat up his food completely;
Unless it consist of sour milk, or honey, or (clarified) butter, or milk, or ground barley, or meat, or sweetmeats.
He must not eat together with his wife, nor in the open air, nor standing, nor in the presence of many (hungry spectators), nor must many eat in the presence of one (hungry spectator).

Let him never eat in an empty house, in a house where the sacred fires are preserved, or in a temple dedicated to the gods. Neither must he drink water out of his joined hands, or satiate himself to repletion.

, Let him not take a third meal (over and above the two regular meals in the mornings and evenings), nor let him ever take unwholesome food. He must eat neither too early, nor too late, and he must take no food in the evening, after having fully satiated himself in the morning.

He must not eat bad food (whether injurious to health or otherwise reprehensible), nor from a bad dish (which is similar to the dishes used by barbarians, or which has been defiled by a wicked man eating from it), nor lying on the ground, nor with his feet raised upon a bench, nor sitting on his hams with a cloth tied round his legs and knees.
He must not have connection with his wife on the eighth, or fourteenth, or fifteenth day of the half-month.
And (he must avoid connubial intercourse) after having partaken of a Srâddha;
And after having given (a Srâddha);
And after having been invited to a Srâddha;
And while performing a vow of abstinence (such as that to be kept on the day before a Srâddha, or the fast to be observed on the eleventh day of the half-month);
And one who has performed the initiatory ceremony of a Soma-sacrifice;
And in a temple, in a burial-ground, and in an empty house;
And at the root of a tree (or shrub);
And in the day-time;
And in the twilight;
And with one unclean (or in her courses);
And while he is unclean himself;
And with one anointed with unguents;
And being anointed himself;
And with one sick;
And while he is sick himself,

He must not have connection, if he wishes to enjoy a long life, with a woman who has a limb too little, nor with one who has a limb too much, nor with one older than himself, nor with a pregnant woman.
He must not sleep with his feet wet;
Nor facing the north or the west;
Nor naked;
Nor on wet (fresh) bamboo;
Nor in the open air;
Nor on a bedstead made of Palâsa-wood;
Nor on one made of the wood of five trees;
Nor on one made of the wood of a tree which has been split by an elephant;
Nor on a bedstead made of the wood of a tree that has been kindled by lightning;
Nor on a broken bedstead;
Nor on one made of scorched wood;
Nor on one made of the wood of a tree that used to be watered with a jar;
Nor in a burial-ground, nor in an empty house, nor in a temple;
Nor with people who are restless of limb;
Nor with women;
Nor on grain, nor (in a stable of) cows, nor (on the couch of any of his) Gurus, nor on the fireplace, nor (in a building dedicated to the) gods.

He must not sleep while the remnants offood are on his hands or face, nor in the day-time, nor in the twilight, nor upon ashes, nor in a place soiled (by excrements and the like), nor in a wet place, nor on the top of a mountain.
Now he must not contemn any one (whether of equal rank, or of higher or lower rank than himself).
He must not mock those who have a limb too little or a limb too much, who are ignorant, or who are poor.
He must not serve low people.
Let him not engage in work that may keep him from repeating (or teaching) the Veda.
Let him wear such a dress as becomes his age,
And his sacred knowledge, his descent, his means, and his country.
He must not be overbearing.
He must constantly consult the holy laws and other (salutary, precepts relating to the acquisition of wealth, wisdom, and freedom from disease).
He must not wear a worn-out or filthy dress, if he has means (enough to procure a new one).
(Even though he lacks firewood or the like necessaries) he must not say to another man,have got none.'
He must not wear a garland of flowers which has no smell at all, or an offensive smell, or which is red.
Let him wear a garland of water-flowers even though they be red.
And (he must wear) a staff made of bamboo;
And a jar with water;
And a sacrificial string made of cotton thread;
And two golden ear-rings.
, He must not look at the rising sun;
Nor at the setting (sun);
Nor (must he look at the sun) shining through an awning of cloth (under which he is lying).
Nor at the sun reflected in a looking-glass or in water;
Nor at the midday sun;
, Nor at the face of any of his Gurus while hie is angry;
Nor at his own image reflected in oil or in water;
Nor reflected in a dirty looking-glass;
Nor at his wife eating;
Nor at a naked woman;
Nor at a man in the act of discharging urine (or voiding excrements);
Nor at an elephant (or other dangerous animal) broken loose from the rope that ties him;

Nor at a fight between bulls (or elephants or buffalos) or the like animals, while he is him self standing in a (crowd or any other) place, from which it would be difficult for him to effect his escape;
Nor at one insane;
Nor at one intoxicated;
He must not throw any impure substances into the fire;
Nor blood;
Nor poison;
Neither (must he throw any of those substances) into water.
He must not step over a fire.
He must not warm his feet (by the fire).
He must not wipe (the dirt from his feet) with blades of Kusa grass.
He must not wash (his feet) in a vessel of white copper.
He must not (wash) one foot with the other,
He must not scratch the ground (with a piece of wood or the like).
He must not crush clods of earth.
He must not cut grass.
He must not tear his nails or the hairs (of his beard or others) with his teeth.
He must avoid gambling;
And the heat of the sun just risen.
He must not wear a garment, or shoes, or a garland, or a sacrificial string which had before been worn by another.
He must not give advice to a Sûdra;
Nor (must he give him) the leavings of his food, nor the residue of an oblation (unless he is his own servant);
Nor (must he give him) sesamum;
Nor (must he point out) the sacred law to him;
Nor (must he prescribe) a penance (for him for atonement of a sin).
He must not scratch his head or his belly, with both hands joined.
He must not reject sour milk or the Sumanas flower (when offered to him).
He must not take off his garland (from his head) himself (but he may cause another to do so).
Let him not rouse (a superior) from sleep.
He must not (by harsh speeches and the like) render disaffected one who is well affected towards him.
He must not speak to a woman in her courses;
Nor to barbarians or low-caste persons.
When a sacred fire, or an idol, or a Brâhmana is near, he must stretch forth his right hand (from his upper garment).
If he sees a cow trespassing upon another man's field, he must not announce it (to the owner of that field).
And if he sees a calf sucking (at the udder of a cow, he must not announce it to the owner of the latter).
He must not endeavour to please overbearing men (by flattering their pretensions).
He must not dwell in a kingdom governed by a Sûdra king;
Nor in one abounding with wicked people;
And he must not live (in a kingdom) in which there are no physicians;
Nor in one afflicted (with a disease or other calamity).
And (he must not stay) long on a mountain.
He must not (walk or otherwise) exert himself without a purpose.
He must not dance or sing.
He must not make a noise by slapping (his left arm, after having placed it upon his right shoulder, with his right hand).
He must not make vulgar speeches.
He must not tell an untruth.
He must not say disagreeable things.
He must not strike any one upon a vital part.
He must not despise himself if he wishes to enjoy long life.
He must often repeat his prayers at each twilight (if he wishes to live long).
He must not play with (venomous) serpents or with weapons.
He must not touch the cavities of his body without a cause.
He must not raise a stick against another man.
One who deserves punishment he must strike in order to punish him.
(He must strike) him upon his back with a shoot of bamboo or with a rope.
He must take care not to revile a god, a Brâhmana, the Sâstras, or the high-minded (Rishis).
And (he must avoid) gain and pleasure repugnant to duty.
(He must avoid) even lawful acts which may give offence to mankind.
On the days of new and full moon let him make a propitiatory offering.
He must not cut even grass (on those two days).
He must adorn himself (with garlands, sandal, and the like).
Thus he must observe established customs.
Those customs, which have been explicitly ordained in revealed and in traditional texts, and which are practised by the virtuous, must always be observed by a righteous man with subdued passions.

By adhering to established usage he attains to old age; this is the way to obtain that state in the next life which he desires, and imperishable riches, this is the way to destroy the effect of (bodily) marks foreboding future misfortunes.

He who observes the usages established among the virtuous, who is a believer in revelation, and free from ill-will, lives a hundred years, eventhough he does not possess any external marks of prosperity.
He must persist in keeping his mind and his organs of sense under restraint.
Restraint of the mind implies restraint of the senses.
One who has acquired complete command over himself, gains this world and the next.
One who has no command over himself, reaps no fruit from any of his acts (whether worldly or tending to the acquisition of spiritual merit).
Self-restraint is the best instrument of purification; self-restraint is the best of auspicious objects; by self-restraint he obtains anything he may desire in his heart.

The man who rides (as it were) in a chariot drawn by his five senses and directed by his mind (as the charioteer), who keeps it on the path of the virtuous, can never be overcome by his enemies (lust, wrath, and greed), unless the horses (unrestrained by the charioteer) run away with the chariot.

As the waters (of all streams) are stored up (and reabsorbed) in the ocean, which, though being filled with them, remains unmoved and tranquil, even so that man, in whose mind the passions are stored up (and dissolved), obtains perfect calmness but not he who strives after the gratification of his desires.
One desirous of celebrating a Srâddha must invite the Brâhmanas on the day before (it is to take place).

On the next day, in the forenoon, if it falls in the bright half of the month, and in the afternoon, if it falls in the dark half of the month, the Brâhmanas, who must have duly bathed and duly sipped water, must be placed by him, in the order of their seniority' (or) of their sacred knowledge, upon seats covered with Kusa grass.
(He must entertain) two (Brâhmanas) facing the east at the Srâddha of the gods (Visvedevâs), and three facing the north at the Srâddha of the manes;
Or one only at each Srâddha.

After having (worshipped the Visvedevâs and) offered a burnt-oblation: during the recitation of the first Pañkaka (pentad) at a Srâddha repast consistingof undressed grain or performed for the gratification of a special desire;
At a Srâddha repast consisting of meat, during the recitation of the second Pañkaka;
At a new moon (Srâddha), during the recitation of the last Pañkaka;

On the Ashtakâs (or eighth days) of the (three) dark halves subsequent to the full moon day of the month Âgrahâyana (or Mârgasîrsha), during the recitation of the first, second, and last Pañkakas respectively;
Likewise on the Anvashtakâs (or ninth days of the dark halves of those months);
He must invite the manes, after having received permission to do so from the Brâhmanas.
Having driven away the Yâtudhânas by strewing grains of sesamum and by reciting the twoMantras (the first of which begins with the words), 'May the Asuras go away;'

He must invite the manes (with the four Mantras), 'Come near, O ye manes,' '(Conduct) them all (here), O Agni,' 'May my (ancestors) come near,' 'This is your (share), O ye manes.' Then let him prepare the water for washing the feet with scented water, which has been mixed up with Kusa grass and sesamum, while reciting (the three Mantras), 'Those standing,' 'Speech is imperishable,' and 'What my mother (has sinned),' and offer it (to the Brâhmanas); let him prepare the Arghya (or water mixed with Dûrvâ grass, flowers, &c.) and offer it to them; let him offer to the Brâhmanas, to the best of his power, Kusa grass, sesamum, clothes, flowers, ornaments, incense, and lamps; let him take food sprinkled with clarified butter; let him look them in the face with the Mantra, 'O ye Âdityas, Rudras, and Vasus;' let him say, 'I will offer an oblation in the fire,' and if the Brâhmanas say, 'Offer an oblation,' let him offer three burnt-oblations.'

After having consecrated the offerings with the Mantras, 'They, who are my ancestors,' 'This is your (share), O ye manes,' and 'This offering,' he must pour (what is left of) the food into such vessels as happen to be there, or (into golden ones at the offering addressed to the Visvedevâs and) into silverones (at the offering addressed to the manes), and offer it first to the two Brâhmanas facing the east (who have been invited to the Srâddha of the gods).

Afterwards he must offer it to the (three) Brâhmanas facing north (who represent his three ancestors, addressing himself) to his father, grandfather and great-grandfather, (and calling out) their name and race.
While the Brâhmanas are eating the food, let him mutter (the three Mantras), 'Whatever (trickles down) through my fault,' 'With days and nights,' and 'Whatever (limb) of yours, Agni.'
And (let him mutter) the Itihâsa (Epics), Purâna (Legends), and the Dharmasâstra (Institutes of the Sacred Law).

Near the leavings let him deposit upon blades of Kusa grass with the ends turned towards the south one ball of rice for his father, while saying, 'Earth is (like) a spoon, imperishable (satisfaction).'
With the Mantra, 'Air is (like) a spoon, imperishable (satisfaction,' let him deposit) a second ball for his grandfather.
With the Mantra, 'Heaven is (like) a spoon, imperishable (satisfaction,' let him deposit) a third ball for his great-grandfather.
With the Mantra, 'Those ancestors whohave died,' let him place a garment (upon the balls).
With the Mantra, 'Give us sons, O ye manes,' (let him place) food upon them.

With the Mantra, 'Enjoy it, O ye manes, partake of it,  imparting vigour,' let him sprinkle the balls to the right with the wet (remainder of the food), and offer the Argha, flowers, incense, unguents, and rice, and other victuals and dainties to the Brâhmanas.
And (he must offer them, ) a jar with water, which has been mixed up with honey, clarified butter, sesamum, and (ointments, oil, and the like).

The Brâhmanas having eaten and being satisfied, let him sprinkle the food (as much as has been left by them) and the grass with the Mantra, 'Mayest thou not fail me,' and strew the food near the leavings; and having asked them, 'Are you satisfied?
